title: Ubiq launches the fifth redeemable NFT
content:encoded:
Ubiq is proud to present POSTER 4 — MINER, the fifth NFT in the ERC1155 Redeemable Poster series.

Introduction

Ubiq is proud to present the fifth redeemable ERC1155 NFT on the Ubiq platform. This was drawn by the talented artist Jopet Arias.

This is available now for 500 UBQ and is only available in a limited quantity of 88. That’s right, only 88 will ever exist.

Available at: https://poster.ubiqsmart.com

Since this is a digital asset, you can buy the poster and hold it. You have the freedom to redeem it later or transfer it to another address. While we don’t currently have a secondary market for NFTs for Ubiq (this is in the works), there is also the possibility to resell an unredeemed token.

POSTER 4 — MINER is a 12 x 18 inch poster printed on museum quality matte paper. Every redeemed poster ships for free worldwide to any country which doesn’t have legal restrictions on imports (Cuba, Iran, Crimea, Syria, and North Korea).

Artist’s statement

As a Digital Nomad since 2010, I saw industries grow and flourish online.
I have observed and recorded the details that affected my art practice.
The most recent is Crypto Art and the blockchain.
As an artist I’m still learning and mining whatever information I can get.
Creating and fusing my Traditional Art practice with it.
While taking part in thriving communities in the metaverse.
Jopet Arias
Thanks for checking in and be sure to follow the blog, Twitter, Github and join Ubiq Discord to help collaborate with the best community on the internet.

title: Announcing Vires In Numeris
content:encoded:
An NFT art project launching exclusively on Ubiq and Token.Gallery

Introduction

Numbers bring wonder and can evoke an emotional response and attachment. It may come down to numerology, mathematics, significant dates or just plain superstition. We all have numbers in our lives.

Vires In Numeris is an NFT art project launching exclusively on the Ubiq blockchain and will be released on the Token.Gallery NFT platform.

Vires In Numeris in Latin translates as “strength in numbers” but it can also be interpreted as “in numbers we trust”. The people involved in this project represent Ubiq, crypto, 10Grans and some early Token.Gallery artists. The goal is to make this a unifying project across our communities.

Details

A total of 101 works (numbers 0 to 100 inclusive) will be released at unspecified intervals. There is no set timeline for this project so it may be weeks, months or even years.

Works will be released on the following verified Token.Gallery account:

https://token.gallery/address/ViresInNumeris

Each work is a 420x420 PNG image. Each number will be minted as an edition of 10 total (not all 10 may mint at once) with 1 edition sent to the producer of the work.

title: Announcing Gubiq 5.2
content:encoded:
This article formally announces the latest version of the Ubiq full node, Gubiq 5.2.

Introduction

Gubiq 5.2 is based on the very latest v1.10.7 release of the upstream Go-Ethereum project and contains around 239 commits merged since the Gubiq 5.1 release that we made in July.

This release has been in testing internally with no issues.

This release incorporates the code that went into the latest Ethereum London hard fork (however does not activate the hard fork).

The next release of Gubiq 6.0 is anticipated to be a hard fork activation release. The hard fork will incorporate both the Ethereum Berlin and London hard fork EIPs. We do not however intend on incorporating EIP-1559 fee market changes which we will reserve for further community discussion.

There may be another minor patch release of Gubiq as the upstream Geth mentions a new security focused release will be released next week:

 — @go_ethereum

Gubiq 5.2

Gubiq 5.2 full node is now available:
https://github.com/ubiq/go-ubiq/releases/tag/v5.2.0

All services which run Ubiq nodes are encouraged to upgrade but this is considered an optional upgrade as there are no hard fork changes. Fusion wallet will be updated to point to the latest version and you will automatically be prompted to upgrade.

Enjoy!

creator: Kris Lester
title: Announcing Redshift
content:encoded:
This article formally announces Ubiq’s first interchain bridge, named Redshift.

What is Redshift?

Redshift is Ubiq’s first multi-directional bridge which allows value transfer between Ubiq and other compatible blockchains. At the time of writing this article Redshift only supports Ubiq to and from Polygon and we have plans to add more networks, such as Ethereum, in time.

Redshift has been built on top of the ChainBridge code with Ubiq core developers making several improvements in code stability, function and design.

Inspiration for the name

In Physics a redshift is an increase in the wavelength, and corresponding decrease in the frequency and photon energy, of electromagnetic radiation (such as light).

Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redshift

By measuring the redshift of nearby galaxies or star systems, scientists can tell the speed and direction at which they are traveling, as well as the relative distance between them.

How does it work

When you want to send funds you need to navigate to the Redshift interface and connect either Sparrow or MetaMask. Once you interact with Redshift from the Ubiq network you will be sending over Wrapped Ubiq (the tokenised ERC20 version of Ubiq) to a contract address, where it is locked and held.

A relayer then detects the interaction and after a certain amount of time mints the exact same amount of wUBQ on the bridged network. The process works the same in reverse, except the contract on the non-Ubiq bridged network burns the wUBQ that is sent, before releasing the locked wUBQ on the Ubiq network.

A more detailed description of how ChainBridge or Redshift functions can be found here: https://chainbridge.chainsafe.io/live-evm-bridge/#lock-and-mint-burn-and-release

There is also a Redshift Tutorial playlist you can follow on YouTube which guides a user through the steps they need to go through to use it.

Where can I use it?

You can find Redshift on the https://ubiq.ninja/ page or alternatively just use the link provided below.

Redshift Bridge

Any questions or technical issues, please check in the Ubiq discord.

Join the Ubiq Discord Server!

title: Odin — A handbook for Ubiq
content:encoded:
Odin — A handbook for Ubiq

The community is proud to introduce a new resource for the Ubiq network called Odin, named for the Norse god who possessed far-reaching knowledge and wisdom.

It is a database of the history, functionality, infrastructure and the surrounding ecosystem and is meant to highlight answers to any question someone might have about interacting with Ubiq.

Whether a prospective developer, miner, node operator or trader; you will find resources to help inform your decisions.

The information available using Odin covers a broad range of topics. There are quick resources like the FAQ section or Infographics, guides such as launching an ERC-20 token or relevant details for deploying contracts on Ubiq.

Other materials run the gamut from more general knowledge ( ex: the Glossary page as an industry dictionary ), to Ubiq-specific resources. Items such as color pallet hex codes, logos, fonts and naming conventions can be found in the Branding section.

Importantly, Odin also includes detailed historical information about Ubiq as related to events such as the Nucleus Block, ESCH airdrops, and UIP votes.

There are also plenty of resources focused on third party Ubiq-compatible products and services. One can find guides about a number of adjacent items such as using hardware wallets like Trezor or Ledger, adding Ubiq functionality to MetaMask (although you really should just use Sparrow), the various pools for mining UBQ, trading on Shinobi, or using Enmaku to add a layer of privacy to your holdings.

Like all things in the Ubiq sphere, this project is meant to garner input and participation from the community at large. Everyone is encouraged to contribute to improving the scope of Odin's knowledge-base.

Initially, suggesting edits and additions or initiating discussion around ideas to help refine the information should be done by visiting the #ubiq-developers channel in the Ubiq Discord. Longer-term, there may be a shift to a more formal method for suggesting changes.

As the Ubiq ecosystem advances and matures, so will the information found within this database. There is currently, and will continue to be plenty of opportunity to contribute.

Skål!

title: Announcing Gubiq 5.1
content:encoded:
This article formally announces the latest version of the Ubiq full node, Gubiq 5.1.

Introduction

Gubiq 5.1 is based on the v1.10.3 release of the upstream Go-Ethereum project and contains around 474 commits merged since the Gubiq 5.0 release that we made in February.

This release has been in testing for over a month internally with no issues.

This release also incorporates UIP 9. UIP 9 has been introduced in a backwards compatible way and brings us greater Dapp compatibility and resolves a LOT of minor issues (because developers assume Chain ID = Network ID) that we have had to debug and fix over the years.

The next release of Gubiq is anticipated to be a hard fork activation release.

Gubiq 5.1

Gubiq 5.1 full node is now available:
https://github.com/ubiq/go-ubiq/releases/tag/v5.1.0

All services which run Ubiq nodes are encouraged to upgrade but this is considered an optional upgrade as there are no hard fork changes. Fusion wallet will be updated to point to the latest version and you will automatically be prompted to upgrade.

Changes

UIP 9 — Change NetworkID to match ChainID

Currently Ubiq’s networkId is 88, while chainId is 8. This should not be problematic, however much of Ethereum’s ecosystem was built with the assumption these values would match (instead of actually following the specification). To make it easier for these Dapps and wallets to properly support Ubiq (without us having to patch/fork each one separately), the networkId is changed to 8 to match the current chainId.

This has been implemented in a manner that allows for a window of time in which clients accept connections from peers reporting both the old and the new networkId (88 and 8 respectively).

This does NOT require a hardfork due to not touching consensus, however the window of time in which both networkIds.

At a later stage networkId 88 will be fully deprecated.

State snapshot system

In this release, the new snapshot mechanism is enabled by default. Snapshots provide O(1) access to state during EVM execution and also serve as the backbone of the snap sync and state pruning features. Note: should you run into any issues with snapshots, they can still be disabled using the --snapshot=false command-line flag.

Snap sync

This is a new sync mode, which is a replacement for ‘fast sync’. In snap sync, the node downloads Ubiq state data much more efficiently than fast sync ever could. With snap sync, we can also finally provide a progress indicator for the state download. Since this is a new feature, and few peers will support snap sync initially, snap sync is not yet enabled by default.

eth/66 protocol

Gubiq now supports eth protocol version 66, which adds request IDs.

Enjoy!

Thanks for checking in and be sure to follow the blog, Twitter, Github and join Ubiq Discord to help collaborate with the best community on the internet.
Ubiq Discord: https://discord.gg/ubiq
Medium blog: https://blog.ubiqsmart.com
Twitter: https://twitter.com/ubiqsmart
Twitter: https://twitter.com/CryptoUbiq (Ubiq Community)
GitHub: https://github.com/ubiq
Website: http://ubiqsmart.com

content:encoded:
Ubiq is proud to present POSTER 3 — TO THE MOON, the fourth NFT in the ERC1155 Redeemable Poster series.

Introduction

Ubiq is proud to present the fourth redeemable ERC1155 NFT on the Ubiq platform. This was drawn by the talented artist Smeagol.

This is available now for 420 UBQ and is only available in a limited quantity of 88. That’s right, only 88 will ever exist.

Available at: https://poster.ubiqsmart.com

Since this is a digital asset, you can buy the poster and hold it. You have the freedom to redeem it later or transfer it to another address. While we don’t currently have a secondary market for NFTs for Ubiq (this is in the works), there is also the possibility to resell an unredeemed token.

POSTER 3 — TO THE MOON is a 12 x 18 inch poster printed on museum quality matte paper. Every redeemed poster ships for free worldwide to any country which doesn’t have legal restrictions on imports (Cuba, Iran, Crimea, Syria, and North Korea).

Artist’s statement

title: Enmaku (6/6) Privacy Tips & Final Notes
content:encoded:
In the last post, we covered how to manage your notes.

In this final post, we’ll go over a few tips to keep you safe when using Enmaku.

Privacy Recommendations

Earlier in the series, we discussed external RPCs’ ability to link your transactions at times. If you can, it’s best to run a local node and point the app and wallet RPCs to it.

If you choose to use external RPCs or even relayers, keep in mind that your IP address can give up your coarse location, therefore it’s a good idea to use a VPN or Tor when using the app.

Once again, it’s also recommended that you use Sparrow instead of MetaMask. Sparrow is a lightweight privacy-focused MetaMask fork that’s been stripped of all MetaMask analytics. This means that when you point Sparrow to your local node, it doesn’t make any external network requests either.

Finally, it’s recommended you use Brave, Chromium, or another open source browser. Brave browser, like Google Chrome, was built on Chromium so extensions like Sparrow and MetaMask can be installed the same way. Brave, however, is open source and built with privacy in mind. By default, Brave blocks cross-origin requests (how most apps collect analytics), so it’s also a lot faster.

Series Conclusion

We hope you learned a lot about Enmaku and privacy with this series. If you have any questions or want to chat, feel free to drop by the Ubiq discord. We’re looking forward to meeting you.

title: Enmaku (5/6) Managing Saved Notes
content:encoded:
In the previous post, we went through UBQ withdrawals with wallets and relayers.

In this post, we’ll cover managing our notes in the Enmaku Interface’s Notes page.

Navigate to https://ubiq.enmaku.io/#/notes.

If you opted in to saving them during deposit or withdrawal, you’ll see some notes here.

Refreshing Notes

When you click the refresh button to the left of Import, the app will iterate through each note and get update its status using the app’s RPC specified in Settings.

By default, this only happens when you explicitly click refresh. To automate this for every time a new block is found, you can go to settings and toggle Auto-update Note Statuses.

Importing and Deleting

We’ll go through a quick demo of deleting and re-importing our notes. Click the blue Select button, to reveal action buttons, then click the select-all checkbox in the table header. The action buttons will be disabled until you select at least one note.

Click the Delete button to open the confirmation modal.

Copy your notes, then confirm to delete. You should have no notes remaining in the interface.

To re-import them, click the Import button above the table, and a similar modal will open. Here, re-enter the notes you just deleted to reveal the Validate button.

Click validate, and like in the Withdraw page, Enmaku will check the status of the notes.

Unlike in Withdraw, in addition to In Pool notes, Enmaku will consider Already Withdrawn notes valid since we’re importing any notes that have ever been used: Spent or Unspent.

Click Import _ notes, and Enmaku will add them back into the interface.

Withdraw

If you re-select any of your notes, you’ll also see the option to withdraw them. This button navigates to the Withdraw page and passes selected notes to its input panel.

Though there are no restrictions for the notes you can send to the Withdraw page, the same rules for withdrawals apply — you can only withdraw unspent notes for one token at a time — but that validation happens in Withdraw.

Copy

Go back to the notes page. To copy your notes, just select your notes and click Copy. New-line separated notes will be copied to your clipboard that you can store or import into Enmaku in another browser/machine.

Compliance

Though Enmaku is a privacy protocol, you may eventually need to trace your transactions. As you learned in Part 2: Deposit, your notes can be used to link withdrawals and their deposits, which may be necessary at some point for compliance.

Using Enmaku’s interface, you can view notes’ deposits and withdrawals, and export them as a CSV file. Select some notes you’d like to run compliance for and click Compliance. A modal will open with this warning.

Once you understand it and trust the RPC endpoint in the app’s network settings, click Generate Compliance. Once it’s finished, you’ll see the status next to each note. You can click Export CSV to generate a CSV file of all the notes’ compliance data.

If you want to view individual note compliance, you can click the status next to the note, and it’ll show you that note’s deposit and withdrawal information.

You can click the back button to return to the list or close the modal to clear the generated compliance information.

In the next and final post, we’ll go through some privacy tips and closing notes.

Thanks for checking in and be sure to follow the blog, Twitter, Github and join Ubiq Discord to help collaborate with the best community on the internet.

title: Enmaku (4/6) Making Withdrawals
content:encoded:
In the previous post, we went through UBQ and ERC20 deposits and the role that notes play in withdrawing them.

In this post, we’ll cover the process of privately withdrawing our deposits with our notes to a new address using both relayers and wallets.

Unlike with deposits, the process for withdrawing UBQ is the same as for withdrawing ERC20 tokens, so we’ll only go through withdrawals with UBQ here.

Navigate to https://ubiq.enmaku.io/#/withdraw.

Relayers

In Enmaku, deposits and withdrawals are just contract interactions, which are always initiated with a transaction. In order to send a transaction on Ubiq or Ethereum, you need UBQ or ETH for gas. So if the gas for a withdrawal is linked to you, then so is the withdrawal itself.

This raises an obvious problem: you need private gas money to initiate a withdrawal, but you need an Enmaku withdrawal to get that private gas money. This catch-22 is resolved with relayers.

Relayers are services run by others for a fee that initiate a withdrawal on your behalf when you don’t have the private gas to initiate it yourself. If you have an empty wallet and some deposits to withdraw, you’d use a relayer to withdraw some UBQ deposits for gas, so you can use a wallet to withdraw your remaining deposits.

Relayer Select

You can open Relayer Select View by clicking on the Change button next to Relayer: None.

The default relayer each time the app starts is None, which means your wallet will initiate the withdrawal. You must manually change this each time the app starts to prevent any network calls outside the host and RPC without you explicitly initiating them.

You’ll see a list of relayers and their URLs.

Each relayer’s status can be found at its base URL and contains information regarding fees, gas price, supported tokens, and version.

To ping a cell and fetch its status data, you can click on the relayer’s cell. You can also click “Batch ping all” to fetch them all and sort by fee.

In the upper right hand corner, you’ll see the relayer’s Supported Tokens. You can also hover over the token icon to reveal which specific pools are supported.

In the lower half of the cell, you’ll find the relayer’s base fee percentage and gas price for each withdrawal.

Because gas is a constant and fee percentage is a scalar, the “cheapest” relayer will depend on which amounts are being withdrawn.

For example, if a relayer’s gas price is 0.01 UBQ and its fee is 1%, a 1000 UBQ withdrawal will end up costing 10.01 UBQ (1.001%) while a 10 UBQ withdrawal will cost .11 UBQ (1.1%).

Since the amount distribution of your notes can affect which relayer is cheapest, after you’ve validated some notes, you’ll find additional fee calculations for your withdrawal in the cell too, and relayers will then be sorted by those.

Once you’ve selected a relayer, click on the back button to return to Withdrawal.

Note Validation

Back in Withdrawal, enter a few notes you used to deposit UBQ into the input panel.

Click on the validate button, and Enmaku will ensure the notes are valid and in the pool.

When Enmaku validates your notes, it first checks that each note’s format is correct, then fetches a list of all the pool’s past deposit events to find yours. This is for two reasons. 1: When Enmaku generates the withdrawal proof using the note, it needs to construct the deposit’s Merkle tree to find the path, so all the deposits are required. 2: If you only fetch your* note’s deposit with an external RPC, the RPC can know which deposit is yours when you do anything with it. The entire event history is retrieved every time, not just when withdrawing, for these reasons.

The first time you validate a pool’s note, it may take a while to download the event history, but since that history is then cached in the browser, subsequent downloads will be much faster.

You should see a status of [Found in pool] for your notes, but if you don’t, it’ll be for 1 of 7 reasons:

  • Wrong token: Enmaku will only withdraw one token at a time. The selected ‘withdrawal token’ corresponds with the first valid note in your list. If you attempt to validate a valid UBQ and a valid ESCH note in that order, the ESCH note will show [Wrong token], and you’ll need to withdraw it in a separate withdrawal.
  • Invalid note format: The note didn’t pass the regex and is incorrectly formatted. Ensure the note is entered exactly how Enmaku first displayed it.
  • Unsupported token: The token symbol wasn’t found in the app, and you may need to add it.
  • Unsupported amount: The token symbol was found in the app, but the pool’s amount was not.
  • Wrong chain ID: The note’s chain ID is incorrect, and you may be using the wrong interface.
  • Never deposited: The note’s format is fine, but its associated deposit was not found in the pool.
  • Already withdrawn: The note has been spent.

If you selected a relayer and validated some notes, you’ll notice a drop card under the Withdraw card, displaying exactly how much will go to the relayer. These numbers are based on the gas price and fee for your valid notes’ amount distribution.

Click on the relayer’s change button again to view the relayer cells.

The bottom half now also has the total percentage fee for your withdrawal as well as how many & which of your withdrawals are supported by the relayer.

As with supported tokens, you can hover over “Total Supported Withdrawals” to view which of yours are supported.

For the sake of explanation, we selected a relayer before validating our notes, but bear in mind that Enmaku will sort relayers by whichever is cheapest given all the information it has, including validated notes.

So if you’re using a relayer, it makes more sense to validate your notes, then ping relayers to choose the cheapest from there.

Relayer Withdrawal

Finally, create a new account in Sparrow or MetaMask and copy the address.

Paste the address into the destination field.

Click on withdraw. A confirmation modal will open.

Once you confirm your withdrawal, your notes will be used to compute proofs that demonstrate you’re entitled to your original deposits.

To keep on-chain verification costs low, proof generation requires more computation off-chain, so it may take up to ~10 seconds to generate each note’s proof.

As proofs are generated, they’ll be sent to the relayer, and you will receive transaction hashes if they were successful.

And once again, just as with the deposit, we can click on “Complete this withdrawal” in the modal to clear the withdrawal session.

Once they’re confirmed, you’ll see your updated balance in your wallet, minus the relayer fee and gas costs.

Wallet Withdrawal

Now that we’ve used a relayer to withdraw private UBQ for gas, we can use that UBQ to wallet-withdraw our remaining notes! Connect your wallet, then validate your notes.

Unless you refreshed the page, a relayer should still be selected from your last withdraw. So to withdraw with a wallet this time, click on change and select None under relayers.

Click on the back button and enter the destination. Since your wallet is connected this time, you can click on the button in the destination field “Connected Wallet” to easily enter your connected wallet’s address.

Finally, click on Withdraw to open the confirmation modal.

Review the summary, and click on withdraw. This time, all proofs will be generated before a batch transaction is sent to Sparrow or MetaMask for confirmation.

Once the wallet’s window opens, confirm all the withdrawals, and wait for their confirmations.

Once they’re confirmed, you’ll see your updated balance in your wallet!

You can now use your UBQ to withdraw your ESCH in the same way, using either a wallet or a relayer.

In the next post, we’ll dive into Enmaku’s note management system, and take a look at the notes we’ve been saving by choosing “Yes” in the deposit & withdraw modals.

Thanks for checking in and be sure to follow the blog, Twitter, Github and join Ubiq Discord to help collaborate with the best community on the internet.

You can now use your UBQ to withdraw your ESCH in the same way, using either a wallet or a relayer.
